Illegal crosses in French public spaces reignite debates over church-state separation
subhead: Calvaries installed on public land in towns in the Alps, on the Mediterranean coast and on the island of Corsica, sometimes with the help of far-right identity movements, have rekindled long-standing tensions around France's 1905 law separating churches and state.

The Rassemblement National wants to reopen brothels
subhead: MP Jean-Philippe Tanguy, who is preparing a bill to create cooperative venues managed by sex workers themselves, says penalizing customers has worsened the situation of sex workers.

headline: Cambodia retaliates against Thailand after air strikes kill civilians and trigger mass evacuations
subhead: The renewed hostilities, after months of sporadic skirmishes and a stalled ceasefire deal, have escalated a century-old territorial dispute and deepened fears of a wider conflict in the region.

headline: Closure of Madrid's Café Central signals a city in transition
subhead: The iconic Madrid jazz venue is set to close its doors in early 2026. The decision has sparked a strong reaction as the Spanish capital faces rapid gentrification.

headline: 'French secularism, once a means to protect individual freedom, has become a tool to defend a supposed national identity'
subhead: As France marks the 120th anniversary of the 1905 law separating churches and state, a coalition of non-profit organizations warns that the principle of laïcité, the French concept of secularism, is being transformed into a system of citizen surveillance.

subhead: Famed worldwide for his saturated images capturing leisure society, the British photographer died of cancer on Saturday at the age of 73.

headline: 'The Voice of Hind Rajab' is more than a film about a child killed in Gaza
subhead: Kaouther Ben Hania's unprecedented work is less a film about Gaza and Hind Rajab, who was killed by Israeli tanks, than it is about our individual and collective powerlessness to stop the horror of mass killings, writes columnist Jean-Pierre Filiu.

headline: 100 years of the photobooth: Meet the people keeping them alive
subhead: Created in New York in 1925, the analog photobooth has come close to extinction over the years. Two passionate restorers, Eddy Bourgeois and Virginie Voisneau, are helping keep the vintage booth alive in France and beyond.
